channel.title: Alisa in Techland
channel.description: Recent content on Alisa in Techland

item.title: Primary Keys in Snowflake are Very Demure, Very Mindful
item.description: All database tables should have a primary key, whether its one column or several.

item.title: Select Statements in Snowflake are Having a brat Summer
item.description: Technically, these features were released before this summer, but I am trying hard to stay relevant here.

item.title: SQL Window Functions: I guess that's why they call it window pain
item.description: In this post, I will try to explain window (analytical) functions.

item.title: How the Snowflake Qualify Clause Changed My Life
item.description: I know what you’re thinking: either this is a click-bait title or Alisa doesn’t have a lot going on in her life.

item.title: Data Engineering Project Idea for People Getting into Data Engineering
item.description: It can be difficult to make a jump between job titles.

item.title: How to Document a Data Pipeline
item.description: This is my very first guest blog, contributed by Jared Rand.

item.title: Views in Snowflake
item.description: Someone asked this question on Reddit trying to build a data mart basically and most of the times it will be file source that will be transformed through ETL and eventually loaded into snowflake.

item.title: Table Types in Snowflake
item.description: Someone asked this question on Reddit trying to build a data mart basically and most of the times it will be file source that will be transformed through ETL and eventually loaded into snowflake.

item.title: A Day in the Life of a Data Engineer
item.description: The point of this post isn’t because I think I’m so awesome that you will all want to know my 1-step smoothie recipe and workout regimen (the 1 step is “add fruit that is near you to a blender and hope it tastes edible” and the workout regime is a strict couch-to-fridge cardio plan); the point is to help people who work with data engineers and the salespeople who market to data engineers understand just what exactly we are looking for in business requirements, project communication, and new products.

item.title: Things I Sometimes Do in Snowflake/SQL That You Should Not Do
item.description: I have turned into a typical old school parent in that I find myself saying “Do what I say, not what I do” This is usually when I’m sharing my screen, and under the perceived time pressure and awkwardness that comes from people watching you work, I take some SQL shortcuts.

item.title: Common Excel Functions in SQL
item.description: My first job out of college was in insurance analytics. I learned a lot about insurance and a lot about Excel.

item.title: A Good Day to Delete Hard
item.description: Deletion method is an important data warehousing concept, one you’d ideally master before an interview.

item.title: Much Ado About NULL Things
item.description: We have to talk about NULLs. This post won’t include anything revolutionary, but rather just a summary of what NULLs are, what they aren’t, and why they are important in data warehousing.

item.title: CTEs versus Subqueries
item.description: I get this question a lot: Is a subquery more performant than a CTE?

item.title: Normal Forms for Normal People
item.description: This post is for my friend Mitch, who, despite his persistent belief that he annoys me with his questions, has reminded me why it’s important that we stay hungry for theoretical knowledge even as we get caught up in our day-to-day work.

item.title: Functions in Where Clauses
item.description: This post is part of a new series of mini-blogs I’m doing on SQL performance tuning tips.

item.title: How to Say It for Data Engineers
item.description: I used to think people who made a big deal out of small syntactical or idiomatic differences were just being pedantic and condescending.

item.title: Cool Things in Snowflake
item.description: The title of this post would be “10 Things I Like to Use in Snowflake That You Could Google but First You’d Have to Know They Exist.

item.title: ELI5 - Primary Keys
item.description: When I get requests to ingest or extract data as tables or reports, I often ask the requestor for the primary key.

item.title: ELI5 - Clustering
item.description: This Explain Like I’m 5 will be about clustering, a technique used by Snowflake, a cloud based data warehouse, to improve query performance.

item.title: ELI5- Slowly Changing Dimensions
item.description: Explain like I’m 5 (ELI5) comes from the popular concept that if you really know something well, you can explain it simply, so a five year old can understand.

item.title: Database Storage
item.description: There are two types of relational database management systems: columnar and row-based, also called: column-wise and row-wise, column store and row store, column-based and row-based, and column-oriented and row-oriented.
I am Alisa (uh-lee-suh) and I am a data engineer. I have other hobbies too.
